newsitem.title: GERMANY: Germany's Herzog urges Europeans to back unity.
newsitem.headline: Germany's Herzog urges Europeans to back unity.

text.p: German President Roman Herzog on Thursday urged Europeans not to underestimate the dangers of what he called re-emergent nationalism, saying it could be contained only by embracing European integration.

After receiving the Charlemagne prize for promoting European unity, Herzog said in a speech that he understood the apprehension among citizens of the European Union about giving up their currencies and allowing the transfer of more power to EU headquarters in Brussels.

The ceremony was overshadowed by the death of former West German defence minister and one-time Bundestag President Kai-Uwe von Hassel who collapsed and died aged 84 as he arrived at Aachen town hall to attend the ceremony.
Herzog urged Europeans to be "Euro-critics" who recognise the problems but support integration rather than "Eurosceptics" wanting to abandon the project altogether.
"If we want to prevent the conflict scenarios predicted by the Eurosceptics evolving into self-fulfilling prophecies, then we must not cede the field now to those prophets of doom," Herzog said.
"The spectres which stalked Europe in the 1930s have not been banished for all time. Everywhere they seem to be re-emerging and we must drive them back again by all the means at our command."
A spokeswoman for Aachen city authorities said veteran politician Hassel had been a regular guest of honour at the annual ceremony for the Charlemagne prize.
Hassel, a Christian Democrat (CDU), was West German defence minister from 1963 to 1965 and president of the Bundestag (lower house of parliament) from 1969 to 1972.
After the Social Democrats (SPD) became the largest party in parliament in the 1972 elections, Hassel remained a CDU deputy in the Bundestag until 1980 and focused on European politics.
Bundestag President Rita Suessmuth paid tribute to the Bonn veteran in an inteview with WDR television as "a great political personality".
Visiting King Juan Carlos of Spain presented Herzog with the prize -- one of Germany's top political awards.
Launched in 1950, the prize is awarded in the western city of Aachen where the Holy Roman Emperor Charlemagne, who tried to convert Europe into a single Christian empire, was buried in 814.
Previous recipients of the prize have been Britain's war-time prime minister, Sir Winston Churchill, and West Germany's first post-war chancellor, Konrad Adenauer.
